newsitem.title: HONDURAS: Honduran inflation up 24.9 pct in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Honduran inflation up 24.9 pct in 1996.

text.p: Consumer price inflation in Honduras rose 24.9 percent in 1996, the highest rate in Central America but down from 26.8 percent in Honduras in 1995, the Central Bank said Thursday.

The increase in inflation largely was due to higher prices for fuel, the slow devaluation of the Honduran lempira against the U.S. dollar and higher food prices, an economist with the Central Bank told Reuters.
Inflation in December 1996 rose 1.1 percent, which was the second-lowest month of the year after January 1996, when inflation rose 0.5 percent, the Central Bank said.
Inflation in December 1995 was 1.5 percent, and in November 1996 it was 2.0 percent.
The 1996 inflation rate far surpassed the government's goal of 16 percent. The government has set a goal of 15 percent for 1997.
